metadata.title: CVE-2018-12020 on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS (trusty) - medium
metadata.description:
mainproc.c in GnuPG before 2.2.8 mishandles the original filename duringdecryption and verification actions, which allows remote attackers to spoofthe output that GnuPG sends on file descriptor 2 to other programs that usethe "--status-fd 2" option. For example, the OpenPGP data might representan original filename that contains line feed characters in conjunction withGOODSIG or VALIDSIG status codes.

    Update Instructions:

    Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2018-12020` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
    by updating your system to the following package versions:

gnupg - 1.4.16-1ubuntu2.5
gnupg-curl - 1.4.16-1ubuntu2.5
gpgv - 1.4.16-1ubuntu2.5
No subscription required

gnupg-agent - 2.0.22-3ubuntu1.4
gnupg2 - 2.0.22-3ubuntu1.4
gpgsm - 2.0.22-3ubuntu1.4
gpgv2 - 2.0.22-3ubuntu1.4
scdaemon - 2.0.22-3ubuntu1.4
No subscription required

python-gnupg - 0.3.6-1ubuntu0.1~esm1
python3-gnupg - 0.3.6-1ubuntu0.1~esm1
Available with Ubuntu Pro (Infra-only): https://ubuntu.com/pro

criterions.comment: gnupg package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '1.4.16-1ubuntu2.5').
gnupg2 package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '2.0.22-3ubuntu1.4').
enigmail: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue (note: 'end of standard support').
python-gnupg package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '0.3.6-1ubuntu0.1~esm1').
